courses.name: Space Debris: Is it a Crisis?
courses.description: The European Space Agency’s short documentary film ‘Space Debris: Is it a Crisis?’ on the state of space debris premiered at the 9th European Conference on Space Debris on 1 Apr 2025.
courses.author: European Space Agency

courses.name: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
courses.description: Space travel is the most exciting adventure for humanity, but in an irony of history we may stop ourselves from going into space the more we do it. With every rocket launched we are creating a deadly trap for mankind.
courses.author: Kurzgesagt

courses.name: Saving Space: The Fight Against Orbital Trash
courses.description: Orbital debris is the stuff of nightmares for astronauts. And with good reason – the amount of rubbish circling the Earth has risen exponentially over the last twenty years as space exploration has grown and increasing numbers of satellites are launched.
courses.author: SLICE Earth

courses.name: The Sky is Falling - A lesson on Space Junk with former NASA Engineer, Linda Dawson
courses.description: Hundreds of satellites and rockets launched into space are left as space junk once they no longer work. An estimated millions of pieces of debris currently orbit the Earth, traveling fast enough to damage or destroy a spacecraft or satellite that happens to be in its path. These objects remain in orbit until gravity pulls them back to Earth, potentially remaining in space for decades.
courses.author: The Museum of Flight

courses.name: Space Safety
courses.description:
How can we prevent satellites from colliding? How can satellites be protected from meteorite impacts? How important are satellites in today’s age? How safe are astronauts on the ISS and why does their research help mankind in general? What happens with space debris distributed in orbit?

In the online course “Space Safety”, the astronaut Dr Thomas Reiter, experts from the European Space Agency (ESA) and other research institutions address the subject matter, presenting possible future scenarios for space applications.

The individual course units cover an array of topics, such as space weather, space debris, collision avoidance, cyber security and space medicine.
courses.author: Technical University of Munich

courses.name: Rocket Science for Everyone
courses.description: This course is an intuitive introduction to rocket science in our everyday lives. Modern life increasingly depends on technology provided by Earth-orbiting satellites, from detailed weather predictions to broad-band internet and GPS. How are satellites launched into orbit and how do they work once they get there? Why are rockets used to get into orbit and how are they different from airplanes? This introductory course is aimed at a wide non-technical audience and is appropriate for all ages.
courses.author: Yale University

courses.name: Space Exploration
courses.description: The course provides an overview of European activities in the field of astronautical and robotic exploration. In the context of ESA's exploration strategy

, scientific goals for the exploration of the Moon and Mars, technological challenges, potential commercial opportunities in the field of exploration, as well as physiological aspects of long-term astronautical missions in low Earth orbit and beyond will be considered.
courses.author: Technical University of Munich
